description: From Middle English dominion, from Middle French dominion, from Latin dominium (“lordship, right of ownership”), from dominus (“lord”), from domus (“house”). See demain, demesne, domain, dominium.

entries.meaning: Power or the use of power; sovereignty over something; stewardship, supremacy.
examples: To choose between dominion or slavery.

entries.meaning: (sometimes figurative) A kingdom, nation, or other sphere of influence; governed territory.
examples: the dominions of a king  the dominion of the passions

entries.meaning: (Christianity) An order of angel in Christian angelology, ranked above virtues and below thrones.
